Posts.Content: You'll look back on all this and realise how strong and determined that you are..  I'm 2 years on from initial diagnosis and my story/situation is very similar  November 2014 I find out that my husband of 25 years is a serial cheat.  December I find a lump in left breast January 2015 I'm accidentally given positive results over the phone by hospital admin worker whilst booking me in for CT scan.  February 2015 mastectomy.  Then it's all a blare until all treatment finished (including divorce)  All is good now, and I look back and wonder how I coped really.  I'm now on the waiting list for diep reconstruction, and although I'm worried about such a big operation, I'm going to put it out of my mind until I get an actual date.  Keep strong, you WILL get through it!
Posts.Title: Bloody doctor

Posts.Content: I can totally relate to that... I found a lump whilst shaving under my arms, back in November 2014. I knew it was going to be bad news.  I went to GP and was referred within a week.  Had all the tests and was told it would be a 10 day wait for results.  4 days later, I received a call from an admin worker at the local hospital, asking me if a particular date was suitable for an ECG.  When I asked what that was for, she told me it was normal procedure before starting chemotherapy!  That was how I found out I had breast cancer..  The surgeon, professor Audisio, was very apologetic as was the BCN, but could not explain why I had been informed in that way.  Anyway, all is well now after all my treatment, apart from the awful aches and pains from the exemestane I take  Best wishes to you, it'll pass by quickly once your treatment starts
Posts.Title: New diagnosis but already knew

Posts.Content: I too was told implants were a no no if you're having radiotherapy. The surgeon I spoke to said she'd had to do follow up surgery on ladies that had implants before radiotherapy, with some patients having to have them removed.
Posts.Title: Tightness in implant area after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I know how you feel... I got my diagnosis in January and I'm now finished with treatment apart from the herceptin etc..  I also faced this alone as I'd found out my husband was having an affair last December.  I have 2 grown up daughters and I don't like to burden them with how I'm feeling, so I just tend to keep my head down and push on.  Sending you best wishes X
Posts.Title: Bi lateral masectomy with immediate construction - I'm terrified

Posts.Content: I have calcium and vitamin D tablets too. I've been on them for just over a year, since them end of chemo.
Posts.Title: Stopping Letrazole

Posts.Content: Hi I too was on letrozole and was switched to exemestane because of the joint aches and pains. They were horrendous!  I have now been switched to tamoxifen even though I'm post menopausal, and I have been taking this for around 6 weeks.  I have NO joint pains or aches now, so I'm quite happy to carry on with it.  I was told by the oncologist that the letrozole and exemestane were the 'gold' treatment and its procedure that you are started on that to see if you're tolerant to it.  He was going to put me on another one but I can't remember the name of it now, but agreed that as its a similar drug the side effects would be similar.  It may be worth giving tamoxifen a try?
Posts.Title: Stopping Letrazole

Posts.Content: It's not normal to get pain from pic line. You should be pain free. I would get them to check it immediately
Posts.Title: Why is my PICC a Pain...???

Posts.Content: I really really wanted a double mastectomy, originally because of the fear of recurrence.  My surgeon, professor Audisio, refused, which I was gutted about.  I wear a prosthesis and it's ok, not great, as you are restricted to what you can wear.  I wished I'd have pushed for the double now but when I next see him I'm going to see about reconstruction and if I don't fancy that I'll ask again for mastectomy
Posts.Title: is double mastectomy easier than prosthesis 24/7
Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Ive been on letrozole for a couple of months now so can't really tell how my hair will be as its only about a centimetre long as yet.  I questioned my oncologist about hair loss with this drug and he said he'd never had any patients with hair loss, but had had elderly patients with hair thinning if you don't mind me asking, how old are you?
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: Insurancewith.com It was founded by a lady who suffered breast cancer I think.  I finished my chemo last year and my premium was £125 for 12 months
Posts.Title: Travel insurance recommendations for Europe

Posts.Content: Hi I was switched from letrozole to exemestane in October as I'd complained about the joint pains.  Exemestane has the same side effects, so I've just resigned myself to them.  Basically, whichever drug you take is going to have the same side effects, as they're doing the same job - that's what they told me anyway.  I find that the less I do, the worse the joint pain is, and it's worse in the mornings.  My oncologist did say that if the side effects become too much to cope with, that I could stop taking them, but I've decided to stick with them for now.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole to Tamoxifen then Letrozole
